 <p style="font-weight: bold; font-size: 18px;"><span style="color: rgb(58, 153, 255);">Case study</span> - Tidal Turbines</p>
</div>
In 2020 a tidal turbine with 12 high frequency hydrophones was deployed in northern Scotland. Each hydrophone sampled at 500kHz streaming 6 million samples per second to shore via a fibre optic cable. PAMGuard ran on a standard desktop PC for two years in real time, detecting likley porpoise and dolphins and sampling various soundscape metrics.

## Export

::: columns

::: {.column width="60%"}

<div style="text-align: left;">
 <p style="font-weight: bold; font-size: 18px;">Export data to other platforms</p>
</div>

PAMGuard has a powerful exporter which can export detections to;

* .mat files which can be opened in MATLAB.
* .RData frames which can be open in R.
* .wav file which can be opened in any acoustics program.

The exporter allows filtering of data based on, for example, species classiifcaton, manual annotatione etc. allowing users to specify exactly what is exported. 

:::
::: {.column width="40%"}

<img src="./images/export_dialog.png" alt="Description of image" style="border-radius: 10px; width: 75%; height: 75%">
:::
:::


## R

Users can also take more control and import PAMGuard data files directly in R using the PamBinaries package

``` {.r}
fizz_buzz <- function(fbnums = 1:50) {
  output <- dplyr::case_when(
    fbnums %% 15 == 0 ~ "FizzBuzz",
    fbnums %% 3 == 0 ~ "Fizz",
    fbnums %% 5 == 0 ~ "Buzz",
    TRUE ~ as.character(fbnums)
  )
  print(output)
}
```

## MATLAB

Users can also take more control and import PAMGuard data files directly in MATLAB using the PAMGuard-matlab library

``` {.octave}
%load a folder of clicks
folder = my/pamgaud/folder
filemask = 'Click_Detector_Clicks*.pgdf'

%load the clicks into a struct array - careful not to load a hige folder or MATLAB will run out of memory
clicks = loadPamguardBinaryFolder(folder, filemask, 2)

%iterate through all clicks and calculate amplitude of the click on the first channel
for i=1:length(clicks)
  clicksamp(i) = 20*log(max(clicks(i).wave(:,1)) - min(20*log(max(clicks(i).wave(:,1)));
end

%plot the results
scatter([clicks.date], clicksamp);
datetick x
ylabel("amplitude (dB)")

```
